Fields.DialogueText: Leningrad, if you feel the need to balance on top of the railing, I'd prefer you do it away from the other officers. I don't want them getting any ideas.
What, are you afraid they'll follow suit? Or are you just jealous, since you know you don't have the equilibrium necessary to pull this off?

Fields.MenuText: You know the officers happily join in every time you act out. I can't trust them to think rationally when you're around.
Oh, yes. I'm so jealous. The envy keeps me up at night, tossing and turning. How will I ever cope?
Actually, I'm more afraid they'll try to push you over the side.

Fields.DialogueText: Amazing what a dynamic leader can inspire the masses to accomplish, isn't it?
Oh, you're so funny, aren't you, Captain? A regular comedian.
I would not be harmed, but I would be impressed at the attempt!
It is no matter. I'm already bored with my balancing act.
I might regret asking, but what are you going to do now?
I figure the Morganas northwest of us might give me something to do. To arms!
I think you mean "battle stations," Leningrad.
@BATTLE
Impressed?
Impressed by their revolutionary spirit to overthrow a leader, of course!
Officer, I've been meaning to speak with...
Leningrad?!
Hello there, Kapitan! Have you really been meaning to speak with me? I feel so honored.
Oh, I'm sure. What did you do with the lookout?
Don't sound so suspicious. He was feeling ill, so I volunteered to take his place. I was looking for something to do, anyway.

Fields.MenuText: You promise you weren't the one who made him ill?
Very thoughtful of you, Leningrad.
You have been especially bored recently, haven't you?

Fields.DialogueText: How would I accomplish that, exactly? Poison his soup? Besides, you know I would never visit harm upon our crew.
When a comrade falters, another must rise and carry the flag forward.
I'll admit, there's truth in those words. The only cure for boredom is to take action.
Morganas! Finally! I could feel my mind turning to mush up here. Come on, Kapitan!
Oh, good grief.
@BATTLE
A bit dramatic, Leningrad. It's only lookout duty.
Leningrad... Wha-?
Kapitan! Would you like some suspicious-looking mush along with the rest of your food?

Fields.MenuText: Why are you serving everyone food, Leningrad?
What's supposed to be in that suspicious-looking mush?
Please tell me you didn't prepare that food yourself. And if you did, please tell me none of the officers have eaten it.

Fields.DialogueText: A Belle, if she truly supports her people, is never above such labor.
Nutrition. Sustenance. Zero percent capitalist extravagance.
Are you still worried that I am trying to poison people? You should trust your Belle a little bit more than that!
You didn't actually answer my question, Kapitan, and you're holding up the rest of the line. What will it be? Mush or no mush?
You know, you have the tendency to get a little demanding when you're bored.
I'm going to throw this mush at you if you don't make up your mind.
*ALARM*
What's that I hear? Oh, yes, it's the alarm. You might as well bring along that mush, Leningrad. I have a feeling it might be useful for repelling the Morganas.
Hmph!
@BATTLE
Leningrad, what are you doing, peeking over the top of that counter?
I'm spying on Officer Halko.
Why? Just... Why?
He told me he likes that woman, Officer Sowa. The one over there, the one reading the newspaper.

Fields.MenuText: Leningrad the Voyeur, I see.
You're not jealous, are you?
I really need to get you some more books.

Fields.DialogueText: Awareness of our crew's well-being is hardly the same thing as petty voyeurism, Kapitan.
A true Bolshevik is above envy, Kapitan.
I assure you, this is not a matter of finding entertainment, Kapitan.
No, no. I'm just interested because Halko's a friend, an actual friend of mine, and I've never had a friend develop feelings for someone before.
You've never? Oh. Well, I suppose I could understand why that might make you curious.
Of course, as long as Halko keeps dragging his feet, he's never going to get anywhere with her. Look at him, too shy to approach her.
I should go over there start a conversation with them...
Oh, no! No, you're staying here. If Officer Halko decides he wants your help, he will ask for it. Otherwise, you should keep your distance.
You ruin all my fun, you know that? Oh well, we have Morganas coming in from the east. We should probably take care of them.
@BATTLE
Whoa! Kapitan, where did all these books come from?

Fields.MenuText: I've no idea. They must have materialized here, out of thin air.
Printing presses.
Books? What books? I don't see any books.

Fields.DialogueText: Goods are the product of labor. Nothing materializes out of thin air.
A wonderful invention, the printing press, placing the power of communication in the hands of the masses.
Ha! Please bring me a rivet gun to repair my splitting sides. Your attempt at humor may overwhelm my structural integrity.
I now fear that, when I called you a comedian earlier, you might have taken me seriously. I was being sarcastic.
Oh, I would have never picked up on that on my own. But, to answer your question, I bought these books for you.
Your attempts at staving off boredom recently – working as a lookout, working in the mess hall, spying on Officer Halko – made me think you might need them.
Austen, Wilde, Carroll, Dumas, Hugo, Dickens, Twain... But, these are all novels! And not even Russian novels, at that.
You already have all of Pushkin and Dostoevsky's works. I thought I might broaden your knowledge of the world's fiction.
I have better things to do than read about an inept girl who falls down a rabbit hole into some drug-induced stupor.
OH? I thought you prided yourself on your open-mindedness, Leningrad? Your willingness to hear anyone's ideas and evaluate them on their own merits.
I'm not sure these even have ideas, much less merits, for that matter. Do I really want to read the sad tale of a middle-class woman unable to find an upper-class husband?
*ALARM*
There's the alarm. I think, once we're done with the Morganas, we're going to have a conversation about how to properly thank someone for a gift.
@BATTLE
Well, I see you've at least taken the books out of their boxes. How are you organizing them?
I have three piles here – one for books I've read and hated, one for books I haven't read but know I'll hate, and one for books I've never heard of.

Fields.MenuText: The pile of books you've read and hated is certainly... tall.
How could you be so sure you wouldn't like the books you've never read?
There are only three books in the third pile.

Fields.DialogueText: Not every pen should touch paper, Kapitan.
I'm confident in my assessments, Kapitan.
Honestly, I'm surprised I needed that third pile at all.
Now, I'm not saying that just because a book is in one of these first two piles, I'm refusing to read it. You were right, I have been bored.
Boredom can propel me into doing things I wouldn't normally. Like reading trashy novels.
I hardly think Les Miserables qualifies as a "trashy" novel.
One - Les Miserables is worse than all of the books in this room, because it's about melodramatic young people who are incapable of competently planning a revolution.
Two – there are Morganas headed this way. However, I would be thrilled, as always, to continue this debate with you after we're done with them.
@BATTLE
You're pacing, Leningrad. Why are you pacing?
I'm deep in thought. Walking is what I do.

Fields.MenuText: I thought you practiced your knife-throwing skills while deep in thought.
I thought you sang along with jazz music playing at an excessive volume while deep in thought.
I thought you recited an oath of allegiance to the Red Army while deep in thought.

Fields.DialogueText: My knife skills have been perfected. Now I mostly pace.
Define "excessive" volume.
Sometimes I do that, sometimes I pace.
But you've made your point, Kapitan.
What's on your mind this time?
You know what? I've made up my mind. If those trashy novelists can write their own books, then I can too!
*ALARM*
Oh, I'm sure this will go over well. That's the alarm, Leningrad. You'll have to shelf your literary plans for the time being.
@BATTLE
Forget I mentioned it.
Leningrad, why are you in my office?
I only just realized I have no writing utensil. And, I figured, you have a desk in your office. Desks and pens usually go together.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not sure I trust you with a pen.
There's an old pen in the top drawer. You could use that.
Knowing you, I think you'd be happier with a pencil and eraser.

Fields.DialogueText: The world trusted a melodramatic fool like Victor Hugo with one, but my own Kapitan does not trust his Belle?
Thank you, Kapitan.
I'll ignore that comment.
Oh... look at this pen! It writes so smoothly! This will be perfect!
Not that one, Leningrad! It's a László Bíró ballpoint pen. It's one of the first produced. It's the best pen I own.
Captain! There are Morganas headed this way!
Just, try not to break it. Or lose it. Or use up all its ink in one sitting, all right?
Your faith in me is just, really, astounding sometimes.
@BATTLE
Is my pen still in one piece, Len... Wait, what's wrong? I haven't seen you look this upset since that whole philosophy debacle with the officers.
Just look at this, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: Where did you find a small child to write sentences for you?
Is this an actual language?
I mean, it's not completely illegible. For the most part.

Fields.DialogueText: UGH! It's even worse than I thought!
Of course it is! Oh, it's no use...
Your attempt to be charitable stings me, but you're right.
I just assumed, since I knew how to read, writing wouldn't be a problem. Apparently, I don't have the muscle strength developed to write like a proper adult.
I'm sure if you practiced at it, your handwriting would improve.
Think of how much time that would take! Surely, there has to be an easier way.
*ALARM*
There's the alarm, Leningrad. Come on, let's go.
@BATTLE
Hello there, Officer Halko. What are you and Leningrad up to today?
Halko's teaching me how to operate his portable typewriter.
Leningrad's so knowledgeable. I think it's terrific she's decided to put some of that knowledge down on paper.

Fields.MenuText: I think I know why Leningrad likes having you around, Officer Halko.
Did you know that, prior to the late 19th century, the word "terrific" had a very different meaning?
I'm not sure the world will be properly prepared for whatever work she produces.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh? I'll take that as a compliment!
I meant it as a compliment, but I think I catch your meaning.
I'm not sure if you share my optimism or not...
What would I do without you here, Kapitan, keeping my ego in check?
It really speaks to the level of trust between you two, that you're able to speak to one another in such an... enthusiastic fashion, and yet ultimately never offend one another.
Trust?
The two of us?
Um...
Hmm...
Moving on to another subject, entirely, Officer Halko was telling me that he and Officer Sowa both participated in amateur theater productions in their hometowns. Interesting, isn't it?
Officer Halko, did you finally work up the courage to talk to Officer Sowa? Good for you!
Um... No, sir. My bunkmate heard about it from her bunkmate, actually. Leningrad, ask me if you have any trouble with the typewriter, all right? I'll see you later.
That went downhill very quickly, didn't it?
Oh, you were very smooth. No worries, though. There are Morganas headed our way. That should take your mind off your blunder for a while, at least.
What would I do without your words of encouragement, Leningrad?
@BATTLE
*Ahaha! HAHA! Hee hee hee...*
I don't hear the typewriter clacking, just maniacal laughter coming from Leningrad's cabin. I should investigate.
On second thought, maybe I should just leave her alone.
But then again, she could be plotting the revolution she keeps talking about. Damn, what choice do I have but to investigate?
*KNOCK*
Leningrad? Are you all right?
Perhaps, but I haven't heard you laugh that manically in a while, Leningrad. What's made you so happy?
I wrote my first sentence! Here it is, typed out and everything!

Fields.MenuText: I have to see this. Does it read like the beginning of a manifesto?
I have to see this. Is it more readable than your attempts at writing with a pen?
I have to see this. Honestly, Leningrad, I'm proud of you for attempting to do this.

Fields.DialogueText: Can any of us deny our formative influences? I think not!
I think you'll be pleased to find that... Wait!
You are? Oh... Then perhaps... Wait!
Nyet, I changed my mind! You can't read it! It's just a single sentence, and I don't want any feedback until I've finished the first draft. You can read it once I'm done.
*ALARM*
You'll have to write your second sentence after we deal with the incoming Morganas.
@BATTLE
Hello, Kapitan! I'm so glad you found me - and yes, I'm quite all right!
What on earth? Leningrad! What happened to this room? Why is the floor covered with crumpled paper?
It's terrible, Kapitan. It wasn't just my handwriting. I'm just a bad writer in general. It's all hackneyed, and cliché-ridden, and horrible.
I'm sure it's not actually that bad, Leningrad. It's your first time attempting to write. You can't expect it to be perfect.
Maybe writing, good writing, is only reserved for those who are actually human. Since I'm not human, maybe there's something missing, something I don't have that real writers do?
Now, Leningrad. I'm going to talk, and I just want you to listen, all right?
But...
No, you're listening. Once I've finished this thought, you can talk all you want. For now, you're listening, okay?
Fine.
Despite the grief I give you on a regular basis, I have no doubt that, given enough effort, you will one day be a great writer. "Effort" is the key word.
Knowledge comes easily to you. Really, a lot of things do. But writing, that requires practice. For anyone. You can't expect to master it immediately.
So, you'll need to decide for yourself... Do you want to put forth the effort to write? Or not?

Fields.MenuText: You can speak now, just in case that was unclear.
Anyone in there? I haven't broken you, have I?
Please tell me you were paying attention while I was talking.

Fields.DialogueText: I was collecting my thoughts, Kapitan.
Give me a moment to organize my words, Kapitan.
I was, Kapitan.
Effort just takes so much... effort. I have to bear witness to the insipid things I put on the page, which might as well be a form of torture, as far as I'm concerned.
If you keep with it, then eventually, you'll bear witness to those words becoming less and less insipid as time goes on.
You better not be lying to me, Kapitan. If I'm going to go to the trouble of practicing, it better pay off.
Also, there are other Morganas headed this way.
Let's take care of the Morganas now. After that, you can tell me all the ways you'll make my life miserable if practicing fails to improve your writing.
Splendid.
@BATTLE
What's that you have there, Leningrad?
Well, I figured that, perhaps, trying to write a full-length manifesto might be too large of an undertaking. So, for my first, real, attempt at writing, I decided to do an essay.

Fields.MenuText: An essay condemning Capitalism and the Free market?
An essay condemning the Morganas for their lack of helpful communication?
An essay condemning the overdramatic young people in Les Miserables?

Fields.DialogueText: An inspiring topic that fiercely stirs my Bolshevik heart, but no.
Ha! What difference could such an essay make unless Morganas were willing to read it?
Oh! My fingers ache to reprimand those fools for... For... EXISTING!
I'll keep that idea in mind for my next essay. This one, though, is about the effect the Belles and Morganas have had on the war thus far.
Coming from the perspective of a Belle, I'm sure it would be an interesting read.
I'm glad you think so, because I was hoping you would... Read it and tell me what you think? What do you say?
That's the alarm, but after we deal with the Morganas, I'd be happy to read your essay.
Spasibo. Really.
@BATTLE
Hello, hello, Kapitan! Have you had a chance to read my essay yet?
About that, Leningrad...
Oh. You didn't like it.

Fields.MenuText: It's not that I didn't like it, it just that... No, I just didn't like it.
You're still a beginning writer, Leningrad. Give it time.
The essay needs a lot of work. There are too many ideas, and not nearly enough organization.

Fields.DialogueText: I see. At least you are honest.
I'm an amateur. Ouch.
Heavy-handed, Kapitan. Then again, I know I would be just as candid if our positions were reversed.
Well, thanks for taking the time to read it, Kapitan.
Damn. I definitely could have handled that better.
Captain, we have Morganas spotted northwest of us!
Thanks, I'll be right there.
@BATTLE
I'm trying to be considerate, Leningrad.
You were! The truth is what hurts, not your criticism.
You're practicing your knife-throwing.
Da, I am.

Fields.MenuText: How much trouble am I in?
You're not going to throw those at me, are you?
I'm sorry about what I said, Leningrad.

Fields.DialogueText: None, Kapitan. None. At. All. I can't say the same for that piece of fruit.
You are never my target, Kapitan.
You have no reason to apologize or retract your words, Kapitan.
I'm not mad at you, Kapitan. It was strange, because I thought I would be. I worked hard on that essay, but I know you look out for my best interests. You didn't want to hurt me.
Very mature of you, Leningrad. I really appreciate that.
If we cannot accept some criticism, we will never grow.
Another mature observation.
And then, of course, reluctance to change the status quo will inevitably result in the rising of the Bolshevik masses to overthrow the source of the oppression.
Uh... That isn't exactly where I would go with the observation. Maybe this has gone a bit off track.
Nonsense, Kapitan. A revolution is precisely how society maintains its proper course!
You hear that? There are Morganas coming. Maybe I can peg them in the head with these knives.
@BATTLE
*THUNK!* (knife hits a bullseye)
Look at Officer Halko sitting over there.
Leningrad, I'd really appreciate it if you wouldn't sneak up on me while I'm holding a cup of coffee.
Maybe you wouldn't be so jumpy if you stopped drinking coffee. Anyway, doesn't he look sad?

Fields.MenuText: He still hasn't worked up the courage to talk to Officer Sowa?
I'm not getting into this Halko situation. Not after putting my foot in my mouth the last time I talked to him.
I drink coffee so I have the energy to deal with you on a daily basis.

Fields.DialogueText: Frustrating, isn't it? His reluctance galls me.
Then I must answer the call to action. Somebody must!
No surprise that a true Bolshevik would exhaust you... I require only the forcefulness of my convictions to compel action!
Surely, there's something I can do for him...
Oh no, Leningrad. I told you not to interfere.
Captain, we have Morganas approaching from the east.
Da, da, I know, Kapitan. We'll talk about this later.
@BATTLE
Enough spying. Let's go, Leningrad.
Leningrad, why do you look so happy? Bad things always happen when you look this happy.
So, I just got done reading a couple of your trashy novels.
What's this? Leningrad reading, and I'm going to quote you on this, "trashy novels"?
Haven't we established how lacking your sense of humor is by now?
My mind's all jumbled after writing that essay. I figured, what better way to clear my mind, than to read something of absolutely no consequence whatsoever?
Oh, boy. Which ones?
Emma and Mansfield Park.
Oh, no.
Oh, yes. While I still think they're entirely ridiculous, I was able to draw out a few ideas I thought I could apply to Officer Halko's situation.

Fields.MenuText: There is no way this ends well.
What was I even thinking, giving you the book Emma? As if you needed more encouragement to interfere in others' lives...
I can't... I just... No. I'm leaving.

Fields.DialogueText: Contrary to your pessimism, I possess confidence in my plans.
Damn! Have I been corrupted by Jane Austen?
Wait! Listen to me!
Kapitan, it's going to be fine! Here's my idea. I'll write a play. It doesn't have to be a masterpiece, but Halko and Sowa could both be in it. Along with some of the other officers, of course.
That would give Halko an opportunity to talk to Sowa, and it would provide the crew with some entertainment. After all, the jazz nights have been a little stale recently.
That's your plan? I mean, it isn't completely terrible. As long as you promise you won't push Halko and Sowa's relationship any more than what you've described here.
I might have to rein in my usual tendencies somewhat, but I think I could make it work. We can talk about it more once we deal with the Morganas up north.
@BATTLE
Come on, Kapitan.
Wait, where are we going?
I want you to help me write the play.

Fields.MenuText: Hahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahahaha...
Have you lost your mind, Leningrad?
That's a horrible idea.

Fields.DialogueText: Quite the thespian, Kapitan. You would make a maniacal villain!
On the contrary. My mind is quite set.
You should evaluate a suggestion before you dismiss it out of hand.
All right, now. Just listen. I have these ideas, swarming around in my head. As you saw with my essay, my ability to organize them coherently might not be the best.
But you, you're more organized. You can tell me when to hold back, how to lay things out so the audience won't end up lost.
You know I'm the captain of this ship, right? Even when we're not fighting Morganas, I have duties to attend to. When am I supposed to help you write this play?
Oh please, I know you have time scheduled for recreation each day.
What do you expect me to do that will help you?
You know how much I love revolts, Kapitan. Without you there to help, this play could "accidentally" send the members of the crew into a riot. Who knows what would happen?
I simultaneously hate you and yet remain in awe of your irresistible charm that always gets what you want from me.
Oh, you know you love me. All right, so we'll deal with the Morganas approaching us. Then, we'll meet in my study room and start writing this play!
As if I ever had a choice in the matter.
@BATTLE
So, what do you think of the first scene?
I'm going to be honest with you, Leningrad. It isn't terrible. In fact, it's actually pretty amusing.
Nyet, don't say that! I'm not supposed to be good at writing meaningless fiction. I'm a serious writer! Philosophy, ethics, that's what I should be good at writing about!
I have to say, your reaction is entertaining me quite a bit. Almost as much as the meaningless fiction you've written here...
Oh, you're the worst, you know that? Why do I tolerate you? Is it your good looks, your charm, or the fact that I am bound by severe regulations?
There's no way that character would respond that way. It's completely out of character.
It's only out of character if you have no imagination.

Fields.MenuText: That's my point. At no point in reality would anyone ever act like that.
All right, maybe you would react that way in that situation. But, we both know how outlandish you are.
Are you saying I don't have an imagination?

Fields.DialogueText: It doesn't exactly have to be reality, does it? Still, I understand your point.
I write what I know, Kapitan.
Forgive me. I allowed myself to become defensive of your criticism.
All right, we'll compromise. I'll tone down her reaction, if you'll admit that the line in Act II, Scene I is one of the funniest things you've ever read.
Yeah, it was pretty great. Did you really just compromise with me? I didn't think you ever compromised.
Captain! There are Morganas headed this way.
Did I? Oh well, we better go take care of these Morganas.
@BATTLE
I enjoy spending time with you, Kapitan. Especially when it's just you and me. Considering how awful you are, that must be a compromise of some sort, right?
It's done. Finally! Look at it, finished, in one piece. It's beautiful!
I see you've wasted no time with production. How's the first rehearsal going, Leningrad?
Oh, I love it so much! I'm getting to order everyone around, and all the actors are being forced to recite words I've written. It's paradise.

Fields.MenuText: Hahaha, that's not entirely surprising.
I somewhat pity your actors.
Just remember not to get too carried away.

Fields.DialogueText: Don't ruin my joy, Kapitan.
You should envy them! They are lucky to finally have a strong, decisive leader...
I've never felt this way before, but I'll try not to let my muse push me too far.
Spasibo again for your help, Kapitan. I know I might have forced you, a little bit, into helping me write, but I really do appreciate it.
You're not getting sentimental on me, are you Leningrad? I thought you didn't do sentimentality.
*ALARM*
What?! Nyet, never. Not me. Is that the alarm I hear? Everyone, we have Morganas moving in! Let's go take care of them!
That was a little odd, even for her.
@BATTLE
Ahem.
Besides yourself, of course.
What's that I see there? Officer Halko and Officer Sowa talking to one another before rehearsal?
I know, isn't it exciting? I don't think they've stopped talking since he finally introduced himself.
Look at her. She looks completely relaxed, and she's smiling wide. She looks invested in their conversation. There's some definite potential there.
Aha! I'm so good.
Because you had everything to do with them getting to know one another.
I had a lot to do with them getting to know one another. Oh! Wait just a moment. Watch as they rehearse this next scene. Isn't it the best?

Fields.MenuText: I had no idea Officer Halko was so good at pratfalls. Oh, and it just keeps getting worse! I questioned it on the page, but seeing it on stage, you were right. It's great!
Officer Sowa's ability to deliver that long string of ranting dialogue, entirely rapid-fire, is impressive.
The extras' facial expressions are killing me. Really, so funny.

Fields.DialogueText: He has great timing on stage... Unlike how he delayed so much in finally approaching Officer Sowa.
He should be your understudy when it comes to disciplining the crew! I'm only joking, Kapitan.
You should see the faces they make when your back is turned!
Oh, they're all doing so well. I'm excited. Was there something you wanted to say, Kapitan?
*ALARM*
We can talk about it later. Let's get to battle stations, Leningrad!
@BATTLE
Forget I said that.
They do have some chemistry, don't they?
They do...
And while they were working on the same ship, they never realized until just now...
Oh? Kapitan?
Must you tap your watch like that whenever I arrive?
I don't like when you keep me waiting, Leningrad.
I've been so busy with rehearsal, I lost track of time, Kapitan. What was it you wanted to talk about?
Sorry, Leningrad, but I found out earlier I have a meeting scheduled for the same time as your play. It's a high-level briefing with some brass at HQ.
Do you think you'll be able to reschedule it?

Fields.MenuText: I can try, but I can't guarantee anything.
No, I can't. This meeting's important, and it has been on my calendar for weeks.
Don't you think it's a little presumptive for you to assume I can easily change the time and date of this meeting?

Fields.DialogueText: I won't pretend I'm not disappointed.
You can't be serious, Kapitan!
It's only one meeting!
You know how hard we've been working on putting this play together, Kapitan. The entire ship's crew is going to be attending. It's going to be a big deal.
A big deal? Really, Leningrad?
What's that supposed to mean?
I mean, we both know you only really wrote this play as an excuse to bring Halko and Sowa together. I'm sure the crew will have a good time watching it, but it's just a silly play.
Leningrad?
I hope you have a good meeting, Kapitan. Now, there are Morganas approaching us from the south. We should probably see to it.
Unless you have an important meeting to attend. Shall I ask her to reschedule?
@BATTLE
Officer Halko, I'm not sure how you put up with Leningrad as well as you do. Sometimes she's just infuriating. She's barely talking to me at all, right now.
Would you like some advice?
If you have advice to give, I would be happy to hear it.
Think of it like this. First, she has a lot of respect for you. Second, the two of you put effort into this play. She was proud of what you created together.
I explained to her why I couldn't come to the play. She should have been more understanding.
Just wait, listen for a moment. Is she disappointed you're not coming to the play? Sure, but that isn't what she's most upset about.
You called it silly. You know how important being taken seriously is to her. Well, someone she respects called something she put time and effort into creating "silly."

Fields.MenuText: Well, when you say it like that, I just sound like a horrible person.

Fields.DialogueText: She doesn't think you're horrible. Normally, she thinks you're the best.
Wait, what? She's... what?
Oh, the lookout's spotted Morganas, Captain. I'll sound the alarm.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*

Fields.MenuText: I was trying to be humble about my own part of it, but yeah... I included her in that, too.
She can be so flippant about other things... I didn't realize how different this one was.

Fields.DialogueText: She's completely relaxed around you, smiles constantly, is invested in whatever conversation you're having.
She doesn't hate you, Captain. In fact...
In fact, what?
That's why she's a fun friend, that's true... but maybe it's different for her when she's around you. In fact...
Leningrad?
Why are you backstage, Kapitan? Aren't you going to be late to your meeting?

Fields.MenuText: I'm here to apologize, if you would just stand still and listen for a moment.
I'm here to apologize, and- Whoa, was that a papier-mâché tank I just saw go by? How did you manage that?!
I'm here to apologize – though I'd appreciate it if you'd put down the prop gun you're holding.

Fields.DialogueText: I will, but I'd ask you to make it quick. Curtain call is in minutes!
Teamwork and determination. Never doubt the capabilities of a Bolshevik!
I can aim in another direction if you'd like. Is that better?
Now, you were saying something about an apology. Apologize for what?
I shouldn't have called your play silly. It was a stupid choice of words.
I was careless, especially considering the amount of work both of us, and especially you, put into the play. I'm sorry. It's a good play, and the audience will like it a lot.
Spasibo, Kapitan. I really appreciate that. Although, we're going to have to delay my play and your meeting for a bit – there are Morganas approaching from the west.
@BATTLE
They never wait for their cue, do they?
That was applause, for sure. Congratulations, Leningrad! It looks as if the audience really enjoyed themselves.
Are those... flowers you're holding, Kapitan? Where did you get them?

Fields.MenuText: I've no idea! They must have materialized here, out of thin air.
Flowers? What flowers? I don't see any flowers.
Honestly, I bought them from a street vendor after the meeting, before I came back onboard.

Fields.DialogueText: Nothing of value comes from thin air. It only comes from hard work! Oh, wait. That was your attempt at a joke.
In your hands! Oh, wait. That was your attempt at a joke.
A street vendor?! Oh, wait. That was your attempt at a joke.
Why do you have them?
Isn't it traditional for actors and crew to receive flowers following a performance? I got them for you.
Oh, right! Of course. For the performance. Well, thank you. I'll need to steal a vase from someone, I suppose.
Well not just for the performance...
Oh... well... (smiles)
Your mark is here. Stand there, Kapitan, and say your lines.
Ahem, yes. Your line. It is in the script, don't you remember? Fine, I will help you.
Another wave of 'em, Leningrad.
@BATTLE
So the Morganas' curtain call was just an intermission, then? No problem, Kapitan - we can handle this! Then we get back to the real play...
Kapitan, was that really applause? Maybe my ears were still ringing from combat, all through the play.
My lines?
No, no, wait. I remember them now. "These flowers are for you, my fearless yet principled and articulate First Comrade." (ahem) "I sailed the Seven Seas looking for my equal, and yet..."
Oh, quite good, Kapitan!
Ssh! Wait for your cue! I'm not finished... AHEM! "... and yet, I have found love within the holds of my own ship. If only this beautiful creature whose horrible penmanship scrawls its way-"
Cut! Stop! Hahahaha! That is quite enough...
Did I get my lines right?
You got everything right, Kapitan. *kiss*
